thread.title: OVERNIGHT HEALTHCARE: House passes 20-week abortion ban | TheHill
thread.title_full: OVERNIGHT HEALTHCARE: House passes 20-week abortion ban | TheHill

title: OVERNIGHT HEALTHCARE: House passes 20-week abortion ban | TheHill
text:
OVERNIGHT HEALTHCARE: House passes 20-week abortion ban By Sarah Ferris - 05/13/15 06:32 PM EDT 
The House easily approved a bill banning abortions after 20 weeks of pregnancy on Wednesday, just months after an intraparty dispute derailed the legislation. 
The legislation – which also requires a 48-hour waiting period, informed consent forms and mandatory counseling for victims of rape and sexual assault before abortions – passed 242-184. Four Republicans voted in opposition and four Democrats voted in support. 
The bill was initially scheduled for a vote in January, but was abruptly cancelled after some Republicans voiced concerns about a requirement that rape victims have to report to the police before they have the procedure. ADVERTISEMENT Several of the Republicans who had opposed the bill then, led by Reps. Renee Ellmers (N.C.) and Jackie Walorski (Ind.), voted for the bill Wednesday.
The bill stands almost no chance of becoming law while President Obama remains in office, though Republicans say it is part of their long game to force abortion back into the courts. Read more here . 
WHITE HOUSE HIGHLIGHTS VETO THREAT: The Obama administration on Wednesday said it was "disgraceful" for House Republicans to push a late-term abortion ban bill that puts up barriers for sexual assault victims. 
"The bill continues to add a harsh burden to survivors of sexual assault, rape and incest who are already enduring unimaginable hardship," press secretary Josh Earnest said. Read more here . 
DRUG COMPANIES WIN IN 21ST CENTURY CURES DRAFT : The House Energy and Commerce Committee on Wednesday updated its medical cures bill to include a controversial provision that would extend exclusivity rights for some drug companies. 
Any drug that is approved to treat rare diseases would be given a longer "exclusivity period," which keeps competitors from selling the same drug, according to the latest draft released Wednesday. 
While praise for the new version was largely positive, the National Health Council condemned the committee's decision to scrap new rules for "dormant therapies," which refers to drugs that meet unmet medical needs. 
The bill is now headed for a markup by the House Energy and Commerce health subcommittee on Thursday morning. Read more here . 
NEW PRESSURE TO KILL 'D.C.'S OBAMACARE EXEMPTION': A coalition of conservative groups want to make sure Congressional Republicans don't let up on the fight to eliminate what they call D.C.'s exemption from ObamaCare. 
Heritage Action for America and Club for Growth are among a half-dozen groups that have joined a campaign called the "No D.C. Exemption," which launched Wednesday. The groups are looking to drive up support for a two-year-long investigation into how members of Congress pay for ObamaCare, which has been led almost single-handedly by Sen. David Vitter (R-La.). 
The group was formed two weeks after Vitter's panel -- the Senate's Small Business Committee -- denied his request to subpoena documents related to the investigation. Read more here . 
Thursday's schedule 
The House Energy and Commerce health subcommittee will hold a markup on 21st Century Cures at 10 a.m. 
The Senate Finance Committee will hold a hearing on Medicare patients with chronic conditions at 10 a.m.
